												Update to the Updates: As of May 2015 they have made it so that in order to access some of features you have to buy a "DLC" which gives you access to the season pass features. So those of us that thought we spend $20 on a golf game just found out that we have to spend more money to get the other half of the game. On top of which the game still has a lot of development left despite the current release status. I felt this information was foremost to what I had to say about the game play that I experienced.Don't get me wrong. With the demise of the Tiger Woods Golf franchise us fairway junkies have been waiting for a game to come along and give us our knee pant, 9 iron fix. This game will be that, one day. Right now the game is being updated side by side with the console build of the game. Very little effort has been put into the controls for mouse users. So you either need to play with a Xbox controller for the PC or struggle to figure out the who what where when and why of how the game registers your mouse movement. There seems to be no ability to control roughly how hard you whack the ball, I still haven't seen much influence from using the fade and draw features. It makes it hard to not want to break your digital club around the electronic trees surounding you on the course. That all being said the game is still in early stages, one day the game might be the next great golf game for both PC and console. One day. Right now they are putting too much into social features like friends lists and competative play, meanwhile very little into the ability to teach players how to use their control systems to get precise shots. I'm no stranger to golf games but I'm having a very hard time being consistant with this game.Edit/Update: I've had the chance to play a few rounds with an XBox controller, and I've found the controls equally as hard to master. I think the problem still lies in not having a meter system either in game or at least as part of a learning feature that help you adjust to the control scheme.As for the rest of the game. A lot has been put into implementing the social features. The game has single, tournament and tour features. I really like the choice of play variety. However unless you happen to bring 3 other golfers in your bag at the bottom with the loose tees good luck. There is no match making feature that I've come across. So if you don't have other players to play with you wind up being matched with imaginary ghost players who represent some of the best players that have played that course. Talk about frustration. As I have said the controls will drive you batty, but it's worse when an imaginary player with a -7 is driving them right to the green, taunting you while you try to work your way out of the sand. The feature was so annoying the do now have a way to turn it off. So obviously this game does want to promote social play. But for those of us who don't have golf loving gaming buddies it would be nice to have a match feature to meet up with other single players for some rounds. I have not used the course making feature, but I've read that it too can be very difficult to use. However there are many well made player designed courses, that is a great feature of the game.While they are constantly improving the social features of the game, the frustration of the controls combined with the under developed ability to actually use the full social interface make all the implemented features still seem far off. I will revisit this game soon hopefuly after some more updates to see what they have done.February 2015 update: I finally uninstalled the game. The last updates have seemed to revert the controls back to being wonky and unpredictable. Which is a shame because right before that I was finally have to have a full round with a negative score. The controls seemed to be getting better. That has seemed to change. I'll check back maybe in the spring or summer to see if after a few more updates if the game has made any improvements.

												First off, while this is marked as a recommended title, there are issues to be aware of.This game is fun, but it's missing some key elements that sports type games need to be an overall good experience. There is nothing in the way of a practice mode, or even a basic tutorial. You're thrust into the game, and left to figure out how to play on your own. I don't understand why there was such an oversight in this design, and the developers even acknowledge the lack of a practice/tutorial mode in a video on their own page. That being said, it is great fun. The courses, while not real world copies, are challenging, and quite rewarding to those that take risks in their shots. The game mechanics are good, and the game is engrossing enough to have you looking for you club, when you've missed a shot by inches, and decide to throw it. The bad is this. I felt like I've played this game before, at least, I've played PGA Golf Games before, but they felt like there was more to it. This feels less than, because it's more simulator, and less casual. Putting is challenging, and there aren't 15 different types of overlays setup for you to use. Instead you get a grid, and a camera you can move. It feels basic, but it's more challenging in the end. If that is what the devs were going for, which I believe they were, then they hit the mark. This is not a Tiger Woods game, this is a Golf Simulator, rage included at no extra charge. p.s. please add some sort of practice or tutorial modes. That's really a rookie mistake.

												I don't get too wound up about my golf game, and it's a good thing I don't. Otherwise, long ago I would have thrown myself in the nearest water hazard along with my clubs. Enjoying a nice day on a gorgeous course is enough. The Golf Club captures this essence in both the challenge of perfecting your swing and the pride of being able to create your own gorgeous courses. But, is that beauty enough?The game's course creation tools are impressive in their ability to not only let you build detailed courses, but the scalability of the tools themselves. You can apply some macro-levels rules to shape your course with simple min/max sliders – like if you want your course as a whole to be hilly or have lots of water – or dive into placing individual trees, objects, and even whales. The menu presentation is straightforward, but there are times like placing water, for instance, where the macro and micro tools can cause confusion on how to exactly get what you want. Regardless, the game puts a lot of power in your hands, and with a little tinkering you soon learn how to efficiently work with the tools and start making some sweet courses.I was really impressed with the naturally adaptability of your holes in the broader context of the world's environment. Moving a hole en masse, rearranging holes' order, adding/subtracting holes, and even switching out the overall theme of the environment (you can choose from desert, autumn/forest, rural, alpine, and the wild Scotland-like links terrain) is well done.You can also dive in and playtest your hole at any time; dropping your ball in a specific location or playing the whole thing. Finding and playing other people's creations is easy as well, and you can use them to put together your own tour of courses.The golf gameplay itself is challenging and satisfying. The right analog swing requires precision, especially when applying draw or fade, and a minimal pre-swing HUD is hard at first. Gauging your swing power while putting, in particular, takes getting used to, but it won't take long to develop a rhythm and feel to your swing.As well-crafted as the game is, it's missing a sense of progression that drives you forward. While creating the course of your dreams (or someone else's nightmares) feels good, I missed a larger structure. Visual or physical golfer upgrades, an overarching rewards system tied to your stats, or even a career shell are missing and there's lost momentum within the game because of it. Seeing what kinds of courses I and others could come up with and the challenges therein is motivating, but the sustenance it provides is impermanent.The Golf Club delivers as a course creator, and it's no slouch swinging the clubs, either. What's missing is the personality: the larger career structure and personal investment in your avatar to spur players on and elevate the experience from a nice set of features to the complete package   9/10Appsy doodles

												This game is turning into a solid golf game, the graphics are great to look at and the gameplay is getting there IMO. The main selling point of this game for me is the GNCD, the course designer. I have spent many hours on this and once you get the hang of it, your only limited by your imagination.This is a worthy successor to the EA TW series and plays a lot like it too, well if you consider that most of the people that worked on that game are the ones that developed TGC. The good thing about this game is the fact that the developers are still working on it and fixing bugs and adding stuff to it all the time, once it’s finished then this will be a solid and enjoyable title for everyone to play. The only real problem with this game for me is the graphics issue if you own an AMD Radeon card, especially the newer models, but I think this is more to do with the Unity engine than anything else, as playing this game with an Nvidia card seems less problematic and appears to run better. Although this game has been developed for the PC it still very much feels like a port, as its main focus IMO is for the console market, after all that’s where the money is.Anyway, if you’re in any doubt about buying this game, then I would recommend you do, especially if you like golf and have been looking for a worthy successor to EA TW series. There are also more updates coming soon, and with the number of courses made by the community, then its longevity is assured. It’s not quite the golf sim this has been hailed to be, as that title I think belongs to another game currently in development.Anyway this is money well spent on.Update: I can't believe that this game has now been out for over 20 months, it has had a lot of fixes applied to it and it certainly has improved since its early access days. Graphics wise this game is great to look at and I can’t fault it on that front, however the gameplay is a lot easier than it used to be IMO, it’s easier to hit straighter shots and plays more like an arcade game rather than an actual golf sim, even with all the aid’s turned off. This game still suffers with issues, originally with AMD cards and then with Nvidia cards, although fixes have been applied to fix the Nvidia issues, I wish the same could be said for AMD users, anyway putting those glitches aside, this is still a great game and I would still rate this up there with the likes of EA TW series. The games real selling point for me has been and will always be the Greg Normal Course Designer and the thousands of community designed courses out there, some of course (no pun intended) better than others. And the great thing about it is that they are all free to play, let’s hope that this stays that way. Player customisation has been cranked up and the variety of shirts and trousers available to dress your player up has increased, but I would like to see more with also some community made ones thrown in too. The selection of golf clubs has not changed and I believe that this is something that could certainly be improved along with the option to hit shots with more back spin etc.If your looking for a game to play against AI, then you'll be dissapointed, although you can play against the "ghost" of other players who have played the courses, whoch is better than nothing I guess. This game does not have crowds, as it was only ever inteneded to be a week-end golfer type of game and not a full blown EA-TW clone as it does not have the PGA logo or backing.This game has only had one DLC to date, which the community was in arms about, but IMO you don't have to buy it, it wasn't like the game was unplayable without it.@King Kyne, for a while I did feel this was a good Sim game, but then I started to play PG and somehow the gameplay in that was a lot harder and felt more realistic IMO. TGC feels a lot more arcade-ish, and since the updates, hitting the ball straight has become a lot easier. The game feels like its holding your hand and not letting you make mistakes too much, it almost feels like its restricting you. I don't associate a SIM game with something difficult, far from it, a SIM should allow you to do your own thing, it then becomes as individual as you. I have played PG for a while now, and since they introduced the horizontal swing mechanics, I personally feel that the game has improved in my estimation, not because it’s become harder, but I can now shape the flight of the ball better, if only it was that easy in real life! The reason the mechanics in PG works for me is that there is an option to create a draw or a fade, make the ball go higher or lower, but it still depends on how you “swing” the club, so it’s down to the player’s skill rather than the settings that you dial up. Please don’t get me wrong TGC is a great game, but it feels like something that you could pick up straight away, while PG is something else and needs practice if you want to get better at it.I guess that’s my definition of a SIM, it needs to feel natural and with enough practice you start to reap the benefits for all that hard work you’ve put in.I play with all the aids turned off in both games, and PG still feels more realistic IMO sorry to say.

												Great golf sim with a few quirks.I love this game - play it several times a week with my Dad. I'd definitely recommend it to anyone who wants a good solid golf game, but it's certainly not perfect. Probably easiest to sum up with a list of pros and cons:ProsThe core of the game is rock solid and realistic. The feel of the swing, the look of the courses, the physics, and the action of the ball are all great. Fantastic course editor - best I've ever seen in a golf game. You can play courses created by other palyers or generate a fresh new course with just a few clicks. You'll certainly never run out of courses to play. Very satisfying when you put in a good round because you know you earned it. :)Skill is not stat based. If your get better at the game it's because you've learned to play better.Devs are still improving the game. I've been playing since the first day of Early Access and the Devs have been communicating and responding - while still sticking to their gameplan. They haven't fixed all the quirks, but the game has seen steady improvements over the months.ConsSome machines might struggle with the graphics. Seems to recquire more CPU/GPU power than you might think. Only a few graphics settings to adjust.The swing controls can be hard to learn. I love the controls (I use xbox 360 controller) but some people seem to get frustrated. No option for the old 'three-click' method that is popular in other games. I think this is part of the 'level playing field' that the devs are shooting for. They have worked hard to make the competition skill-based and fair.The interface is sometimes clunky. All the info and controls are there, but sometimes they are not intuitive.  Took me a long time to figure out what the two different distances on the putting green were (one is distance to the cup, and the other is the distance to your aiming marker). I still can't figure out how to properly show an instant replay. :)No career mode or similar extra features. The Tiger Woods games were full of all sorts of extras and some people might expect them here. Presentation is somewhat sparse. The voicover/commenter is well done, but there is very little 'juice' or graphical embellishments to spice things up.For me the pros definitely outweigh the cons. This is one of my most played games of 2014 and I expect it will be in 2015, too.

												There is a huge lack of golf sims out there - remember Microsoft Golf, Arnold Palmer Links, and of course Tiger Woods? Now there are basically The Golf Club and WGT. And between the two, I'll take The Golf Club any day.The graphics are good - I won't say GREAT - and the sounds/speech is good (although the commentator gets a bit annoying after a bit). Mechanics are solid, certainly better than the ridiculous 2 click meter used in WGT. If you like real swing method using your mouse, rather than clicking on a meter, TGC is for you. It doesn't quite rise to the level of the swing meter on Tiger Woods - which I consider to be the best golf game ever - but it's not too far off. All in all, you can play 18 (or 9) holes and have a darned enjoyable time; for true golf enthusiasts, this is probably as close to the real thing as you can get without lugging your clubs out to the local links.A few negatives: the match-making. NOT easy to jump into a multi-player game against real people. The menus are not very easy to navigate, despite their initial appearance with large labelled icons. You have to click and click and click to find a course to play, set up the paramaters and match type and difficulty, then when trying to find opponents to play TGC will automatically locate "players" and fill your roster to the number you have selected (2, 3, 4, etc). The only problem - no guarantee you will actually get REAL players. Once the round starts, most of the time you find yourself playing "Ghosts" of the actual players. I.e., they are not logged in, but TGC selected them based on their skill levels, rating on the course you are playing, etc - and popped their "ghosts" into the game with you. Huh??? So, 8 times out of 10, you will find yourself playing against basically 2 or 3 other computer AI players. Needless to say, not a very social occasion. Try chatting with them. The ONLY way you can play against other REAL live people is if you manually select someone you have "Friended" and who you KNOW is in the game. If they aren't in the game, and you locate them by UserName, you will just get their "ghost" again. You CANNOT just randomly play games against other live players. This is one of the biggest faults in this game to me.I do find the game fun, but there is .... something... missing. Hard to put a finger on it. Individually, all the components of a great golf game are there. But put together, it falls a bit short, and I wish I could describe specifically what that is. Difficulty-wise, it IS hard to get below par (and I've played a ton of golf games for a lot of years, and consider myself pretty darn good). Putting especially is a pain in the butt. There is NO power meter. On ANY swing. So you have no real idea how hard you are swinging.  There is NO swing meter, so you have NO idea how far your backswing is. There are NO bars period. You just totally wing it. Most of the time just pulling all the way back on the mouse for a full swing works, but what about that sand wedge just off the green? It says it is 40 ft from the pin, and your wedge has a maximum distance of 50 ft, so you don't want to do a full swing - but how do you judge what the right backswing is? 80%, you think? OK - so how do you swing the club back around 80%? No meter=no way of knowing how far back you are swinging your club. Again - you just wing it, and 9 times out of 10 you will wind up doing a full swing even though you didn't want to. Or you overcompensate, and wind up doing a little 20% chip that sends the ball 2 feet. VERY annoying. I read all of the other reviews saying they LOVE this aspect, but they are "purists" who think that any kind of power or swing meter is "cheating." Whatever. If I want that level of realism, I'll go play real golf at the local course. For a game - I want at least some idea of how hard I am "swinging" my "club."All in all, I give this a thumbs-up, but to be honest I have stopped playing it very much due to the swing mechanics described above. If they ever add a power/backswing meter, and if they make it so you can actually play REAL LIVE people randomly -  I will be reinvigorated to play, guarantee it. In the meantime, if you love golf and virtual golf games, you will definitely enjoy this game, even though it may not rise to the top of your "Favorite golf game" list.

Many things.First and foremost this game does not run well. The console versions now have more HB created cources, 2 more course creator themes, and more bug fixes than the PC version.With this last point in mind, I cannot recommend this game. 												((I wanted to add this info to top afterwards, since I failed to mention this before:Unless one specifically goes offline or play the offline-single-player-mode "Seasons", all the shots are recorded to online-storages, which is really amazing to me considering I've gotten to a point I semi-refuse to play "hitscan-client-side-detection-only"-games and such without replay-systems nowadays.Unfortunately currently the replay-system is very barebones with only the playback option available, this far-cry to systems like "Mario Golf Advance + Toadstool"-tour had.But hopefully this system will get further improved in the sequel / 2.0-update (AKA. "The Golf Club 2").)) The Overview:Alright, since the game currently is more closer to "complete"-golf-game nowadays, I suppose it's finally a time to give an overview on this title.First of, what "The Golf Club" is:- "Bare-bones "just golf""-game with emphasis on simulation.What "The Golf Club" is not:- "Arcade-like"-golf game with "Career"-modes to become stronger, more "bling", or anything else similar: It's "Just-golf".I personally have nicknamed this game as "Tiger Woods PGA Tour Online "without gorilla-suit" and with perma-TrueSwing-mode"; not much else to comment about that aside that both games are / were quite well built into Unity3D-engine.((Those who are interested though, the "Tiger Woods PGA Tour 12 - Masters" is quite similar both the UI and the golf-play-wise, minus of course the (identical) "Greens Fee" and other things that were in "PGA Tour Online."))In other words for the most part your avatar customization is mainly limited to "etique"-abiding outfits.And your golf-equipments are standardized performance-wise, meaning that there are no "power-golf-clubs". There might be more "style-suiting" equipment-options available in future (E.G slightly more wider+lighter-clubs to allow pitching from tougher spots with less "carry" due lessened-weight), but that's just one personal wishful-thinking.((Fair to mention that I personally mainly play with the least amount of "assistance-UI" as possible (green-grid, shot-direction-reticle, wind-indicator, and such), to which I base my overview on))As hinted earlier, the players are also limited to "semi-TrueSwing" system, since it's by design that there is no "traditional 3-click-system" in-game to emphasis on more "feeling"-gameplay instead of being cold-hard-mechanical.Unfortunately at the moment, there is no "dry-hitting" so playing by just "the feel" alone isn't necessarily working for the favor of the players.And since the "hitting-indicator" isn't currently working exactly in real-time either (it appears only after the hit is done), the game turns unfortunately into quite fiddly "percentage"-game because players are semi-forced to number-crunch with the "lofts" of their clubs if they want to make more accurate shots. So in the end the hitting-game (currently) is mainly limited to adjusting the loft of the clubs and hitting with max-power, since for the most part the "fine-tune-club-action" seen in various other "TrueSwing"-game is quite non-existent.Point being, the swing+putting-system could be better since it's currently heavily dependant on "power" only (indicated by how "back" you "Pull" the clubs). But it suffices, somewhat.As for the courses (of the amount which in theory are infinite), I personally can only give a / some warning(s): Given that the major-amount of the courses are done by "everyday-non-pro"-players, there are going to large amount of courses not following the "official" (real-life) recommendations; This is very important thing to remember, especially if you're into regular tournament participations.- Especially before the "Out-of-Bounds" (or "O.B")-system was implemented in, there is large amount of "Trap-courses", meaning that if you are very unfortunate to hit your ball into one of the "trap-valleys", you're going to be guaranteed end-up getting that "+9" (or any other "max-hit"-amount set).- Since the game doesn't yet support the "cup-place-randomization", you're going to end seeing a huge amount of these placed in the middle of "spiral-macaroni"-greens.What I am trying to say is the a quite a little amount of course-designers follow the following recommendation: "A player putting from above the hole should be able to stop the ball near the hole." Okay, that is just one part of the whole thing....For those who are interested for more info, here are few links:http://www.barryrhodes.com/2011/11/position-of-hole-on-putting-green.htmlhttp://www.randa.org/en/Rules-and-Amateur-Status/Guidance-on-Running-a-Competition.aspx?chapter=4&section=2In overall, "The Golf Club" is a nice change in the golf-game scenery in which you can simply jump-in and jump-out freely without need of worrying whether your have enough good "gear" or otherwise "stats" to simply play both by yourself and competing with other players.The issues mentioned above aside, the gameplay itself is pretty solid.And this game  isn't all that power-demanding alongside the game itself is being quite stable (at least on my quite low-spec-computer).On a extra note, the game also features a quite extensive API for those people who'd like to make more organized leagues and similar organizations.This allows websites such as tgctours.com to have more accurate data on the players themselves.Who knows though what the developers will eventually bring to this game; the possibilities are almost unlimited!

YouTube™ Video: Analog Reviews: The Golf Club 

			Views: 2,288		

			Trent hits the links in The Golf Club to see if EA's golf franchise finally has some worthy competition. Please like and subscribe for more reviews, gameplay, and discussions!		

It's been quite some time since golf fans have been spoiled for choice. EA has dominated one of the worlds most regal games for more than a decade and those who play games on a PC in particular have been left with little to no choice in how they hit the links. Enter The Golf Club, a new Golf simulator from HB studios that doesn't boast PGA licensing or tons of product placement, but it does offer a massive game changing feature that is sure to land in the fairway with most virtual golfers: a course editor. Instead of shelling out absurd sums of money for new courses players now have access to a surprisingly robust course creation tool with Greg Norman's name slapped across it. So does The Golf Club burst on the scene like Tiger Woods circa 1997 or does it choke like Sergio Garcia on Sunday at a major? Without PGA licensing, The Golf Club feels more like a virtual golf outing with friends than a tense and competitive sports simulation. There isn't a character creator, no RPG like leveling or character progression, no unlockables nor upgrades. The Golf Club also doesn't offer any alternative modes like challenges or mini games. You simply pick a course or a tournament and hit the links. Asynchronous play is generally the preferred play mode if you don't have good buddies available for eighteen since it allows brisk competitive play. Your competitors strokes are shown as you take your own and minimal load times keep the pace up and reduces the tedium present in other golf titles. A generic announcer provides the only semblance of professional golf tournament ambiance since galleries of spectators, scoreboards and tournament sponsor signs are all absent from the game's courses. The announcer does a decent job of reacting to your shots and making accurate assessments of the conditions on the course, but his personality is on par with a rusty, dinged-up pitching wedge. It's a shame that HB studios didn't utilize the freedom of not being a PGA licensed product to offer some more festive commentary a la Gary McCord at the 1994 Masters Tournament.  The Golf Club's bare bones feature set and lack of atmosphere and ambiance are not it's most prominent offense however, its the fact that the actual golf mechanics feel woefully underdeveloped. The game seems to favor a grip it and rip it mentality as any attempt I made to be clever with my shots ended in utter disaster with the exception of the instances in which the game decided to make some sort of idiotic club selection—teeing off on a par five with an 8-iron for instance. Speaking of club selection a clunky interface makes proper club selection tedious. Players must enter the scout camera mode to see where their ball may end up with a solid shot and if players wish to see where a different club might place the ball, the scout mode needs to be exited and a new club selection needs to be made. Spinning the ball or controlling draw or fade is slightly awkward with a shot modifier that needs to be dialed in before making a stroke. There is also very little feedback when trying to control the strength of your shots. Taking a few yards off of a stroke becomes an exercise in frustration since the difference between 70% and 100% power is a millimeter of travel on the analog stick and there are no meters or other visual indicators to allow players to get a feel for it. If there is another way to modify the strength of your shots I could not find it and a tutorial was not provided. The game's bare bones approach also means that you are stuck with a fixed club selection so don't expect to carry a hybrid or a long iron in place of your five wood.  Thankfully, the course editor in The Golf Club does not disappoint. Offering desert, links, alpine, rural and autum tile sets and a wide array of props, the course editor easily allows players to build realistic courses with few limitations. A number of sliders that populate the world with vegetation, water and hills automates some of the more tedious aspects of design. Bridges, wildlife, structures and props allow you to breathe life into each hole and imbue your course with some personality. Editing can be done hole by hole or freely across the entire course. Coupled with the game's mostly pleasing visuals it's exciting to turn your vision into a virtual reality and then share it with the world. It's just a shame that the frame rate can be slower than the senior tour—even on powerful hardware. The Golf Club brings to mind all of those 1990's home designer software packages available in most electronics stores. Teeing off in The Golf Club is underwhelming but creating courses is any golf fan's dream. The actual golf is a bit clunky and in need of a swing coach with it's poor feedback, lack of club selection, and cumbersome UI. The lack of atmosphere and character progression do little to incentivize actually playing the game. While The Golf Club hasn't quite passed Q School, it's not entirely irredeemable. With so few choices for PC gamers, The Golf Club is worth considering for serious golf fans, those on consoles have a little more to consider but the course creator is quite compelling. In the end, The Golf Club logs a bogey on the score card.

												I originally gave this game a thumbs up, but after so many hours of frustrations and things that don't or half work I am done with it. I almost punched my monitor the last time I played out of frustration. In the 90 hours I have played I think I have uninstalled this game at least 6 times due to rage quitting, only to reinstall it again the next day and giving it an other go. So the game was already frustrating from day 1, but the game also has a lot going for itself so I kept comming back for more. Enough is enough now, the frustrations while playing the game are not healthy for me. If the frustrations were the result of my own errors and bad playing it would not be a problem, but the game coding and design is to blame here. Issues:There are so many times that the game doesn't register your swing (with the mouse) properly and you end up hitting the ball with 70% power. You spend already 45 minutes on a course trying to hit the best you can and then the game just screws it up by not registring your swings while you hit just as hard as the other swings that got registered as 100% power. It also can happen that the ball mid air takes a sharp right/left turn while you swing straight. And no this is not due to ball effect or wind, it is the game that again not registers your swing correctly. It almost feels as a prescripted 'bad swing'.There is a course creator, which in itself is a great feature. The game laysout a random course for you with a course generator. After that you want to edit it, but you have to do that through an afwul User Interface with sub menu's. After 20 hours I was still searching for the right feature constantly. The editor also lets you NOT edit vital parts of the course, good luck adding fairway to raised land, it won't let you. A nice guy on the forum tried to help with explaining a way to bypass the flaws of the creator, but after almost 30 hours in the creator without having made even 1 decent course I gave up, it's not worth the hassle.Also things like Alt Tabbing out of the game and then opening the game again keeps the game in windowed mode. Pressing Alt Enter to go to full screen again opens an other instance of the game while not closing the windowed instance on the background... so you have now 2x the game running with 50% less FPS. Press Alt Enter more times and it keeps adding running instances of the game in the background.This game could be a great game and in between the frustrations I did had fun, but there are things wrong under the hood of the game that sucks the fun out of it and makes it unnecessarily a frustrating flawed game. The community seems pretty decent and helpful, it's not their fault.They are creating a TGC2, I sure hope it will not be as flawed as this version.The game has a lot of potential and it could definitely be my favorite golf game, but they really need to try to get all the nice features and ideas implemented with better coding under the hood and preferably with an other game engine that is more optimized at rendering 1000+ trees and water and stuff. Sadly after +90 hours and an initial thumbs up it has become a thumb down.Still, if you see this game on a nice sale, grab it. It will give you some hours of fun. Early Access Review
								So, I've been mostly trying to stay away from early access games, particularly story driven games, which, in my opinion, are very ill suited for early access.  However certain types of games are well suited for early access, and sports games fall into that category.  Plus, I was really desperate for a golf game, so I took a chance and picked up The Golf Club.This game has a ton of potential and is already in pretty decent shape, for something this far from being finished.  The game is very playable right now, even though many modes and features are missing, as is to be expected of an early access game.I really enjoy the mechanics of the game.  This is not your standard 3 click fare.  I have yet to play with the mouse, but gamepad controls work really well.  You aim with the left thumbstick and swing with the righ, pulling back to wind up, then pushing up to swing.  Hitting standard full power shots is relatively straight forward.  Intentionally hitting a slice or hook to get around an obstacle, or doing a 3/4 swing is much much touchier and riskier, as it should be.  There is also less hand holding than in most golf games, which is great.  You need to figure out effects of wind and such on your own.A highlight of the game is the course creation tool.  While it's missing some templates at the moment, as well as a lot of features, it;s already a really good and robust tool.  With a few parameters you enter the tool will procedurally generate a course in seconds, then you can tweak the course to your heart's content.  There are already hundreds of user made coursed published, some hastily slapped together or nonsensical, but many really beautiful and well made.In conclusion, this game is already pretty good, and it will only get better from here on out.  I definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a golf game.

												I've been playing PC golf games since Mean 18 back in 1986. This is a game I'd give a "meh" to more than  just Yes or a No, but considering the lack of development the last few months I'm giving it the thumbs down. That's mostly due to the launch condition of the game. There are some sins that should not be tolerated by the public and the launch of this game was abysmal.The Golf Club is a pretty mediocre representation of golf with issues that have been around since it launched in early access - inconsistent swing meters, very poor performance, dull voice overs, varying object qualities, iffy physics, overpowered wind and a few other problems. Anyone who claims this is a "simulator" doesn't understand the meaning of the word. You can tweak your shot, but the shot mechancis themselves are uninteresting and (unfortunately for multiplayer) extremely easy to "cheat" with. Edging with the mouseswing is a common problem online and in virtually every match you'll run into someone who is using it to hit every shot dead straight. The career mode was released later and is DLC, which didn't make me too happy considering the massive release problems. Customers should have gotten more for their loyalty and patience.That doesn't mean that the game is totally horrid. If you're lucky enough that the game runs well for you, then you're less likely to run into the swing meter issues (they're often based on sudden frame rate drops). Get the right course at the right time of day and the game can be quite attractive. The course designer isn't as powerful as some, but it's quite easy to use and the pregeneration of terrain is something that is a great idea. It's a Power to the People course designer and you'll see lots of them, some of them quite clever.The devs are hit and miss. They are not bad folks, but they knew a lot of these problems existed and rushed the game out the door to match the console release (and it's quite obvious this is a console golf game first and foremost). So fixing obvious problems like the green grid not working or being able to retract your course from the public (if you accidentally published it) have gone lacking. The short game is another place in this that the game is abysmal - forget trying to hit half or three-quarter shots because the mechanics don't lend themselves to doing so. Some of these issues have been subsequently fixed. Some have not. The post-December patch seems to have improved performance. They've stoped farting  around with trying to boost the user ratings of their own courses. In short, they've made progress. This is the good part. However, it's still not a simulation and there's no way I'm giving this a thumbs up because of the horribly botched release and months of inaction of their part.However, the swing is still tempermental and relies on frame rate to achieve 100%. Turn the settings up and the swing meter goes wonky. And now there's too many really lousy courses to comb through, so finding something worth playing has become an exercise in futility. What's worse is that you can't even provide any kind of decent feedback and to rate the course you still have to complete the round. Who wants to complete a round on a course that sucks? That's both the good and the bad part of having a designer that will spit out somewhat ready-made courses. You simply get an overabundance of stuff to choose from but then finding a good course is like looking for a needle in a haystack.Personally, I find that Perfect Golf simply "plays" a much better round of golf. Then again I'm partial to that Links 2003 style of approach to golf. YMMV but I'm glad this isn't the only PC golf game on the market. Long story short, good effort, mediocre execution, questionable development...equals thumbs down (or at least buy only on sale). I can't recommend this at full price.

												A quick history about me and golf games; I've been interested and played golf games since the early LINKS series on DOS/Windows, as well as Tiger Woods, and other iterations throughout the years. I haven't played a game on the PC in years, and purchased this game during the Early Access period.First impressions! Beautiful landscapes, variety of enviroments, endless courses to play (thanks to generation and community games), native controller support, Couch COOP and online modes! The feature set is impressive, and the controls seem natural and well thought out. It's an easy game to get into, but a tough game to master, exactly like golf. :) Playing online with friends is a bit different, as you are set to play simultaneously on the same course by default. You can however, change it to 'Alternate Shot' by a quick visit to the menu. No relog required.Some nice changes I'd like to see! I'd like to see more variety in the player creation (more clothing options, more customizability), as well as customized clubs or bags for an added touch. These would be flavour items only, and provide no additional benefits (as the game is designed). The game could also benefit from a bit of an easier way to join friends games, such as using the Steam Menu 'Join Game'. Summary - A beautifully designed, well executed golf game, with procedural course design and an endless pool of community talent, this may be the best golf game ever released on PC. 								This review was inspired by some of the forum posts i have seen of late. Many are complaining that it's difficult, other's try to compare this to tiger woods. The biggest complaint is the fact that this game is difficult, it has not indication of where the ball will land, you cannot change your power on the swing as effectively as in every other golf game. If you are a real golfer, you will know that golf, is part luck and part experience. In real golf you cannot really control the strenght of your swing, your golf club is designed for a set distance and momentum does the rest. You can adjust your stance and swing to give you an INeffective swing which is then called a chip, punch or a pitch. These types of swings are created by constraining the swing of the club. GC does the same. You cannot see where the ball is going to land IRL, you hope it's going to land where you want it to land, this is what GC does. It's not always possible to have a 100% power on swing in real life, this is what CG does.Now if these are going to change, i would not know, but it sure as hell stops the above avarage scores from happening less than often. Along with the course designer, you will always have to think to play and not run in like a pro and finish 24 below par. The game has some performance issues and there are a few hiccups, hence the ALPHA state. There are however a few recommendations that will turn this into the best Golf game i have played to date. Having a stamina meter or the option to play randomly created golf courses of your friends will really make this one shine.For those seeking something easier, run back to your Mario Golf or PGA tiger woods games and stay away from this one. Early Access Review
								Even from the start of The Golf Club's early access campaign, the player had access to one of the best golf engines on PC since the Tiger Woods franchise stopped being developed for computers. The swing system demands a controller, and if you read the forums, you will see that people trying to use a mouse and keyboard are quite sore over the current implementation. However, with a controller (in my case, the XBox 360 controller for PC,) the swing system is incredibly intuitive and challenging! You never feel cheated off a bad swing, as the stick-based swing reads your pull back and push forward incredibly accurately, and if you fade or draw your shot, you know it was because you did not shoot a good shot! With an analogue stick controller, the swing system is the best, most challenging, but most rewarding golf simulation on PC right now. Note, as a design choice, the developers have already said that they will never develop a 3-click system or a similiar power meter. They feel that their swing system is incredibly important to keeping the simulation feel of the game, and they think that a power-meter system will cheapen the game. Please make note of this, and do not buy this game, if you are expecting a Hot Shots Golf or Mario Golf type system!Aethestically, the game is a bit lacking. The game does not have any real progression for your character - you can play rounds, tours, or other competitions of varying length and difficulty the moment you boot up the game. The challenge comes from the rounds that other players have finished, and you are competing against ghosts of their low scores. This can make the game feel a bit lonely, but they have slowly been adding more functionality in, such as the ability to play your friends live if you both play the same course, and you can even switch on a turn-based system to make it feel like the two (or three, or four) of you are alternating shots. The multiplayer feels a bit patched together and enough features are missing that it still feels a bit unprofessional, but ever since launch they have been fixing bugs and adding new content. Once full-stat tracking goes live, the game will become much more interesting as you challenge your friends in a variety of skills.The game includes a full course editor, and this is incredibly important, as the game ships with only a few courses developed by the dev team. However, playin custom made courses is an absolute breeze. You can view player-made courses just as easily as the developer made ones, and a 0.0-10.0 rating system allows you to mark your favorite courses, and see which tee's the Golf Club community think are top notch. Already there is a wonderfully recreated version of Augusta National, and I'm sure more PGA-tour courses are going to be developed by the community.This is very important as well, as this indie, small-studio game does not have the PGA tour license. There are no professional golfers at all in the game - it instead makes you feel like you are a club or amateur player getting their turns on a huge variety of courses set in a huge variety of difficulty levels. As you get better you can choose to play near impossible courses where the fairways are narrow strips of land between two lakes, or you can choose to hone your short-approach and pitching skills on a variety of par 3 courses. As more high quality replications of real life golf courses are added to the game, you will begin to see a product that more closely resembles the Tiger Woods games of the past. I read that this indie studio was originally contracted out to make the analog-swing stick system for previous Tiger Woods games, and their pedigree at making an incredibly well rounded golf engine shows. However, you can also see that they have very little experience creating the rest of the product. The UI is very minimal, the announcer volume is best turned to 0 after a round or two, and there is almost no flash or style in the presentation itself.Despite this, there are many other benefits than just the solid swing system. There is no loading time between holes once you load the entire course. Like real life, you can see the other holes around you when you're on the course, and as soon as the ball rolls into the pin, you are onto your next drive. They recently made shot adjustments more challenging - in early versions of the game, it would tell you exactly how many feet you were adding onto or off your shot by changing the angle of your shot higher or lower. Now, it only shows a percentage of your full shot power, making the system more challenging and realistic. In the future, I would love to see some official branding, such as official golf clubs, clothing, and other gear. However, I know it is an indie studio, and at the end of the day, they have made an incredibly well rounded golf SIMULATION that is absolutely terrific at doing what it advertises - letting you experience rounds of golf on a near-endless supply of courses. The developers have been constantly tweaking, refining, patching, and adding new content into the game since its early access launch, and despite a few early stumbles, the game seems to be well on its way to being the best golf simulation on PC. If you liked the Tiger Woods games, or if you think you would enjoy a golf game that challenges you to be perfect nearly every shot, like the game does in real life, this is a must-buy for you! Golf fans, please do not sleep on this purchase simply because it doesn't have the pomp that EA golf games have. As the community adds more high quality content and the developers further refine the game, this has the potential to be a long lasting success!As of July 19th, I rate this game an 8.1/10.0Go buy it; I need more friends to compete with!!!

												Look at my hours played, well over 1000, so I can't possibly give this game a bad review. I love the game, but it's simplistic, basic, and lacks almost every option you can imagine. I am a casual video golfer, I want to hit most fairways, hit most of the greens and score better than par. It is pretty easy to do that in this game. Read the reviews and System Requirements, this game renders the whole course at once, so no load times between holes, but you need a beefy pc to play it the way it was intended and you MUST have version 11 of Direct X Pros/cons depending on how you look at it:There are basically no options in this game, I don't really ever see many options in its future, it is just a simple golfgame where you can relax and play a round of golf like an average joe on the weekend. Everyone uses the same clubs, you can only drive the ball about 270 yards without wind, but you will get wind as they won't give you the option to play without it.The game currently has over 70 thousand user courses, but not easy searching for the ones you will enjoy playing.The Greg Norman Course Creator is an awesome addition as I enjoy playing a different course every time I play, this is a good thing as very few courses warrant a second play.No lobby for multiplayer, but you can play a friends ghost ball or play a live friend with almost real time results.Putter - Putting feels greatWoods - driving is brainless, you can do it while argueing with the wife, if you can move the control stick backward and then forward you will be a star.Irons - I like themChipping and Flops is probably way too easy for most hard core golf gamers.Rating:Gameplay - 7/10Graphics - 7/10Fun - 8/10Golf Options to make this a great game. 2/10Manual or ingame tutorial - None - 0/10Optimized - Game runs on the Unity Engine, either the engine is weak or a bad choice to render whole course at once or their coders can't optimize it as they seem to dummy stuff down with each new addition, like the engine can't handle anymore or the code is running amok. 3/10I guess this game is a buyer's beware game, you'll either love it or it will run like a 2 legged dog.I really enjoy this game. Yes, I think it could be better with some freakin' Options, but that ain't gonna happen.My overall rating would be 6.5, but I really enjoy this game and I have to play on medium with a Windows7 Home Premium, service pack 1, AMD FX 8120 Eight core processor, 3.10 Ghz, 8Gb Ram, 64bit OS, Nvidia Geforce GTX 560 2 GB card.OK.  Vitality’s S&T ReviewsShort and Tasty… The Bits that matter Short StoryGet your score cards out because this is a HOLE-IN-ONE!OverviewThe Golf Club is a golf simulation video game developed by HB Studios on the Unity game engine. It is a golf sim, boasting a powerful Course Creator based on the procedural generation of courses. The Course Creator can generate a brand new course in seconds which can be shared and played immediately online with friends and other gamers.Vitality’s ThoughtsThese mixed reviews are SERIOUSLY insane! I was very hesitant on actually purchasing, But boy am I glad I did.I'm coming from Tiger Woods 08, And I seamlessly transferred into this modern take on the sport without any issues.People complain about the putting, but again I have no problem with it. Yes it takes getting used too, but come on this is a GOLF simulator, People realise how FRUSTRATING this game can be right ? There's a few negatives I do have with it though, When I play 4 player game modes and we create and edit the player names I would like the system to remember the names I've set for them and there outfits, So We don't have to customise them every few days we are going to be playing. Right now it just defaults them to (Name_1) not the name I've set for them.I also wish I could disable the ball following lines, and also speed up the ball when in mid flight.This game IS GOOD though, I don't think it's exactly worth the $40 price tag, and the way they sell stuff can be a little dodgy, as the season mode is a paid DLC but they're minor, If you can get the game for under $30 it's well worth it.Pros:  Amazing Graphics, Wildlife, And Plants Great Simulation of a frustrating sport Course creation is amazing, You'll never get bored playing the same 10 courses The Commentator isn't generic and annoying like most games Won't cost you $50 for a pack of real balls to lose in the creek Cons:  Player Customisation is limiting 4 Player mode should save custom players Some HUD options for lines etc would be nice Pricing is a little dumb founding. (I believe in DLC, But for Season mode?) ConclusionGreat golf simulator, Probably the best on the market right now, I would highly recommend the game to any avid golfer or anyone who wants to play a golf sim, Don't look at the game though if you're after an arcade Tiger woods though. I'd also recommend the game be purchased under $30, But if you've got the money you won't be  disappointed.79/100
